ity

religion at the Hopkins, sponso
red
jointly by the National Conference
of Jews and Christians and the University. Dr. Russel's lecture was
the first of three which he is to present dealing with the "Historical
Aspects of Catholicism."
Dr. Russel, in his opening lecture
,
concerned himself chiefly with
the
Christological controversies of the
fourth and fifth centuries. These controversies centered about the question of the nature of Christ and
the
doctrine of incarnation.
Development Of Controvemy
After the period of Roman persecution it was easy to become
a
Christian and many new convert
s
poured in bringing with them questioning minds. One of the first
issues
was provoked by the doctrin
e of
Arius, a theologist of Alexandria,
who was one of the leaders
of the
intellectuals of his time, and who was
unconsciously fighting the battle
for
paganism. The doctrine maintained
that Christ was not God and
that
there was no such thing as God
becoming a man.
The orthodox Christians also
had
very able leaders the chief of which
was Athanasius. The fight betwee
n
the two men assumed large proportions and resulted in the convoca
tion of the Conference of Nicea
by
Constantine in order to draw
up a
definite and binding Christian
creed.
This conference marked the -crushi
ng
of Arianism and the adoption
of the
true Christian creed.

OR WILLIAM H RUSSEL
SPEAKS ON CATHOLICISM
First Lecture Of Series Of Three
Dealing With
Catholicism
On Monday eitenidg, Dr. Willia
m
H. Russel, of the Catholic Univers
ity
of America, Washington,D.C.,opened
the second series of leetures on
religion at the Hopkins, sponso
red
jointly by the National Conference
of Jews and Christians and the University. Dr. Russel's lecture was
the first of three which he is to present dealing with the "Historical
Aspects of Catholicism."
Dr. Russel, in his opening lecture
,
concerned himself chiefly with
the
Christological controversies of the
fourth and fifth centuries. These controversies centered about the question of the nature of Christ and
the
doctrine of incarnation.
Development Of Controvemy
After the period of Roman persecution it was easy to become
a
Christian and many new convert
s
poured in bringing with them questioning minds. One of the first
issues
was provoked by the doctrin
e of
Arius, a theologist of Alexandria,
who was one of the leaders
of the
intellectuals of his time, and who was
unconsciously fighting the battle
for
paganism. The doctrine maintained
that Christ was not God and
that
there was no such thing as God
becoming a man.
The orthodox Christians also
had
very able leaders the chief of which
was Athanasius. The fight betwee
n
the two men assumed large proportions and resulted in the convoca
tion of the Conference of Nicea
by
Constantine in order to draw
up a
definite and binding Christian
creed.
This conference marked the -crushi
ng
of Arianism and the adoption
of the
true Christian creed.
